author: @ktivnews
title: Nebraska family of three, four daycare children survive collapse of home during 2014 tornado
text:
NEAR STANTON, Neb. (KTIV) - One of the first targets of an EF-4 tornado, which formed on June 16, 2014, was the Kremlacek family’s farm home northwest of Stanton, Nebraska.
Inside were Troy and Amy Kremlacek, Amy’s son 11-year-old Christian, and four young children in Amy’s in-home daycare. It took the tornado seconds to reduce the home to rubble trapping all seven inside.
When the day began, the family knew something about June 16th would be different. “I remember it was real hot, humid in the morning, but kind of felt like a normal day,” said Troy Kremlacek. But, by the time Troy Kremlacek finished his errands in nearby Norfolk, Nebraska, things changed. “I don’t know how to describe it,” Troy Kremlacek said. “But it was just like, when he walked out the door, it just took your breath away.”
Thirteen miles away, at the family’s home northwest of Stanton, Nebraska, Troy’s wife, Amy, could feel the change, too. “It was just so heavy,” said Amy Kremlacek. “I mean, it almost made your chest hurt, it was so heavy.”
Normally, the Kremlaceks would sit outside and watch storms roll in. But not this time. “I made the kids come inside because I just felt like something wasn’t right,” said Amy Kremlacek.
The Kremlaceks had been through bad storms before. The week before, a fierce hailstorm sent them to the basement. “I used that day to teach the kids how to do a tornado drill,” said Amy Kremlacek. “And they, you know, they all knew to put their shoes on, they all knew to grab their blankets so they could cover their heads, and where to go in the basement. So, we had practiced it.”
So, when the Kremlaceks heard the sirens sound in nearby Stanton, Amy gathered the four children staying at her in-home daycare, and her own son, Christian, and went to the basement. “It sounded like a train only it’s right there,” said Troy Kremlacek. “You are right beside it.” “Troy was right,” said Amy Kremlacek. “It did sound like... it sounded like a train coming at us. And I looked at him and I said, ‘Wow, that’s really heavy rain.’ And he said, ‘that’s not rain.’ “It was just loud man,” said Troy Kremlacek. “Destruction. And, stuff was hitting. Hitting me. And I thought I needed to stay standing. Nope. That’s when hot water heater hit me.” “And then all of a sudden the house came down,” said Amy Kremlacek.
Briefly knocked unconscious, Troy woke up... to find his world turned upside down. “First thing I saw was Christian,” said Troy Kremlacek. “I couldn’t see Amy or the kids. So, and that’s when panic set in.” “I can only see myself and one of the child on my lap and the child next to me,” said Amy Kremlacek. “So, I could just see the three of us and then I was talking to the other two children that I could hear down there still.”
Amy’s son, Christian, managed to crawl through a small opening in the debris, and climb out. “I remember getting out there and just yelling ‘it’s all gone’,” said Christian French. “Everything was flat, and like it got steamrolled. It was unbelievable.”
Amy managed to call 911. And, one by one, rescue crews got everyone out, safely. Troy spent three days in a local hospital with a concussion, “compression syndrome” in his legs, and a torn rotator cuff. Amy had “compression syndrome” in her legs, too. When they were well enough to return, utter devastation greeted the Kremlaceks. “It was heartbreaking,” said Amy Kremlacek. “Everything that we had both put together to combine our family because we had just gotten married a few weeks before this. It was gone.”
Thankfully, the community came together to donate everything the Kremlaceks had lost. “I mean, you know, in the world that we live in, you never know how people are going to be, but they really stepped up and they were amazing to help us a situation where so many did so much,” said Amy Kremlacek.
That restoring their faith, and the family acknowledged faith’s role in their survival. “There’s no other way to explain it... it, we were... we had a higher power watching over us that day,” said Amy Kremlacek. “Yeah, we had to have somebody looking over it,” said Troy Kremlacek.
Troy Kremlacek had actually been through this before. On May 8th, 1996, a tornado destroyed the home he was living in, in Beatrice, Nebraska.
To see more stories from our Pilger tornadoes special, follow this link.
Copyright 2024 KTIV. All rights reserved.

author: @RTLFrance
title: Haute-Savoie : une avalanche fait deux morts dans le massif du Mont-Blanc
text: Deux personnes, un homme et une femme, sont mortes dans une avalanche de 200m de lonh ce jeudi 28 décembre en début d'après-midi dans la station de Saint-Gervais (Haute-Savoie), au pied du [Mont-Blanc](https://www.rtl.fr/actu/justice-faits-divers/haute-savoie-le-corps-d-un-alpiniste-disparu-depuis-20-ans-decouvert-au-mont-blanc-7900080214). Trois skieurs ont été touchés, rapporte France Bleu Pays de Savoie. Le troisième est indemne - un moniteur de ski -, a indiqué la préfecture du département. Les victimes se trouvaient sur un secteur hors-piste de la station de ski, à 2.300 mètres d'altitude, quand ils ont été surpris par une avalanche partie à 2.400 mètres d'altitude environ et qui a dévalé 400 mètres. L'équipée était composée de huit personnes. Plus de trente personnes ont été mobilisées pour tenter d'aider les skieurs de l'avalanche : des gendarmes du PGHM de Chamonix, du groupe montagne de gendarmerie, un sapeur-pompier du groupe montagne de Haute-Savoie, six pisteurs secouristes du domaine skiable, deux équipes cynophiles et deux médecins urgentistes du Samu 74. Seul l'un des trois skieurs portait un appareil de détection des victimes d'avalanche (DVA). Les recherches pour retrouver le corps de la seconde victime se sont poursuivies jusqu'à la tombée de la nuit. Une enquête a été ouverte par le parquet de Bonneville. Elle devra déterminer les causes de l'avalanche. Afin d'assurer la sécurité et la qualité de ce site, nous vous demandons de vous identifier pour laisser vos commentaires. Cette inscription sera valable sur le site RTL.fr. Vous recevrez ponctuellement sous forme de notifciation des actualités RTL. Pour vous désabonner, modifier vos préférences, rendez-vous à tout moment dans le centre de notification de votre équipement. author: Mateo Zapata Correa
title: No hay camas para atender a más lesionados con pólvora: Secretaría de Salud de Antioquia
text:
Antioquia
No hay camas para atender a más lesionados con pólvora: Secretaría de Salud de Antioquia
En la actualidad hay 32 camas ocupadas por esta contingencia, cuando en esta región ya son 66 lesionados.
Compartir:
Archivo
La secretaria de Salud en Antioquia, Marta Cecilia Ramírez, confirmó que, a un poco más de 15 días de finalizar la temporada de Navidad y Año Nuevo, no hay camas en el departamento para atender a cualquier lesionado con pólvora que requiera hospitalización.
Ramírez explicó que el Hospital San Vicente de Paul, en Medellín, es la única entidad que cuenta con toda la capacidad para atender a esta población, y en caso de necesitarse otra atención, el departamento debe buscar ayuda en otras regiones del país.
Le puede interesar: Planes de emprendimiento beneficiaron a 590 personas con discapacidad en Medellín
Agregó, por ejemplo, que en este momento hay 32 camas ocupadas con personas lesionadas con pólvora, por lo que la alerta se agudiza, pues aún restan otras jornadas como es la celebración de Navidad, Año Nuevo y el puente de Reyes, donde históricamente muchas personas no atienden el llamado de no usar pólvora y terminando siendo víctimas de los artefactos explosivos.
A propósito de los casos más recientes, las autoridades indicaron que un menor de 17 años y otra persona de 18, en Necoclí, en las últimas horas se lesionaron por estar manipulando papeletas.
Le puede interesar: Alcaldía de Medellín anuncia que se suspende la medida del pico y placa: ¿Desde cuándo?
Hay que decir que, a 66 personas aumentó la cifra de lesionados con pólvora en Antioquia.
Entre los lesionados se encuentran 21 menores, 6 personas que han sufrido daño ocular y 6 que han presentado amputaciones, afectaciones que dejan secuelas para toda la vida.
Acuerdo de paz
De otro lado, desde la cárcel de máxima seguridad del municipio de Itagüí, este jueves, 19 de diciembre, líderes de las estructuras delincuenciales urbanas del Valle de Aburrá firmaron un compromiso de Navidad y año nuevo.
Uno de los primeros en participar fue Sebastián Murillo, conocido como Lindolfo, quien hizo uno de los anuncios más destacados de la jornada.
De acuerdo con Murillo, a partir de ahora, llegan a la mesa de conversación, personas como José Leonardo Muñoz, alias Duglas y el actual gestor de paz Diego Fernando Murillo, alias Don Berna.
Entre los compromisos firmados, según la senadora y representante del Gobierno Nacional en la mesa de conversación, Isabel Cristina Zuleta, se encuentra el cese de homicidios y las llamadas fronteras invisibles en el Valle de Aburra.
Fuente: Sistema Integrado de Información

author: Waqas Arain
title: Polymer Emulsions Market: A Surge Towards Sustainability and Innovation
text:
In an era where the construction and building industry is witnessing an unprecedented boom, the global polymer emulsions market is riding a wave of growth, projected to escalate from a valuation of US$30.9 billion in 2022 to a staggering US$58.2 billion by 2031. This surge, translating to a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 6.9% over the forecast period from 2023 to 2031, is fueled by a confluence of factors including the burgeoning demand for bio-based polymer emulsions and the ever-evolving construction sector. However, the journey is not devoid of challenges, with fluctuating raw material prices and the quest for low-VOC products standing as significant hurdles. The COVID-19 pandemic further complicated the scenario, disrupting supply chains and manufacturing activities, yet it simultaneously spotlighted the critical role of health and hygiene, especially in the healthcare and construction sectors. With Asia Pacific at the helm of the market in 2022, the region is poised for continued dominance, thanks to rapid urbanization and industrialization shaping its landscape.
The Catalysts of Growth
The construction and building industry's insatiable appetite for innovative materials has been a primary driver of the polymer emulsions market. The quest for sustainability has further propelled the demand for bio-based polymer emulsions, aligning with global environmental sustainability goals. These emulsions, known for their low VOC content, are increasingly preferred in applications ranging from paints and coatings to adhesives, underscoring a shift towards more eco-friendly construction practices. Moreover, the versatility and efficiency of polymer emulsions extend their applicability across various sectors, including automotive and textiles, further broadening the market's horizon.
Navigating Through Challenges
Despite the optimistic growth trajectory, the polymer emulsions market faces its share of turbulence. Fluctuating prices of raw materials, a perennial concern, continue to pose significant challenges, affecting production costs and market stability. The pandemic-induced disruptions threw a spotlight on the vulnerability of global supply chains, compelling companies to rethink and reinforce their logistics and distribution strategies. Additionally, the increasing demand for low-VOC goods, while opening new avenues, also demands substantial innovation and adaptation from manufacturers, pushing them to explore advanced formulations and production techniques to meet stringent environmental and health standards.
Asia Pacific: The Market Leader
Asia Pacific's dominance in the global polymer emulsions market is a testament to the region's rapid industrialization and urbanization. The construction boom in countries like China and India, coupled with the region's expanding manufacturing base, has created a fertile ground for the polymer emulsions market to flourish. Furthermore, the region's commitment to environmental sustainability and the growing awareness of green building practices have amplified the demand for eco-friendly polymer emulsions. With governments across Asia Pacific implementing regulations to curb emissions and promote sustainable industrial practices, the region is expected to maintain its leading position in the market, serving as a beacon of growth and innovation in the polymer emulsions landscape.
As the global polymer emulsions market sails towards a brighter horizon, it is propelled by the twin engines of technological advancement and sustainability. The construction and building industry's evolving needs, coupled with the global push for environmental conservation, set the stage for a dynamic market landscape. While challenges like fluctuating raw material prices and supply chain disruptions test resilience, the market's robust growth trajectory underscores its critical role in shaping a sustainable future. With Asia Pacific leading the charge, the polymer emulsions market stands on the cusp of a new era, marked by innovation, sustainability, and unprecedented growth opportunities.

author: Huma Siddiqui
title: PM Modi to inaugurate historic BAPS Hindu Mandir in Abu Dhabi - World News | The Financial Express
text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has accepted an invitation that holds great significance in the cultural and spiritual landscape—the inauguration of the BAPS Hindu Mandir in Abu Dhabi on February 14, 2024.This auspicious event, confirmed by the temple authorities, follows a formal meeting where the invitation was extended by Pujya Swami Ishwarcharandas and Swami Brahmaviharidas, alongside the board of directors.Nestled in Abu Mureikha along the Dubai-Abu Dhabi highway, the BAPS Hindu Mandir is set to become the first traditional Hindu stone temple in West Asia. Its roots trace back to 2015 when Prime Minister Modi’s visit prompted the UAE government to allocate the land for this historic project. Cementing his connection further, Modi virtually participated in the Shila Pujan in 2018.Swami Brahmaviharidas expressed anticipation for the inauguration, terming it a millennial moment of celebration, underscoring its grandeur and cultural significance. Prime Minister Modi resonated with this sentiment, characterizing the temple as an ideal spiritual space—a meeting point for diverse cultures and civilizations, symbolizing spiritual harmony and progress.The hour-long meeting at the Prime Minister’s residential office was marked by discussions between the BAPS delegation and Modi. Key topics included the global significance of the temple and its alignment with Modi’s vision for India ’s spiritual leadership on the global stage. Discussions delved into the Abu Dhabi temple’s role in fostering global harmony and Modi’s overarching vision for India’s spiritual leadership.During the meeting, memories of Pramukh Swami Maharaj and his centenary celebrations surfaced, prompting Prime Minister Modi to extend heartfelt prayers for Mahant Swami Maharaj’s health , the esteemed president of BAPS. In a touching gesture, Mahant Swami Maharaj’s personal invitation was presented to PM Modi, affectionately describing him as “Pramukh Swami na Priya Putra Modi Saheb” or “The most beloved son of Pramukh Swami Maharaj, Modiji.”Expressing gratitude, Prime Minister Modi commended key individuals, volunteers, and supporters involved in the BAPS Hindu Mandir project in Abu Dhabi. He specifically recognized Chairman Ashok Kotecha, Vice Chairman Yogesh Mehta, and Director Chirag Patel for their significant contributions, acknowledging them as sources of pride for India on this momentous occasion.
